awd_titl_txt: Probing and Engineering Cell Membrane with Graphene
awd_abstract_narration:
With the advances in graphene nanoscience there has been tremendous interest in applying graphene for biological and biomedical studies, due to its attractive physical, chemical and biological properties. Significant research endeavors are ongoing to explore its potential applications for drug delivery, tissue engineering, biosensing, diagnostic imaging.  Cholesterol is an organic molecule, an essential building block for cell membranes. However, the knowledge on the cell membrane and its cholesterol contents is limited due to the lack of methods to explore membrane cholesterol dynamics and its relationship with other biomolecules. Recent studies have shown that graphene can directly and selectively interact with cholesterol in cell membranes and subsequently modulate the cellular structure and function. In this project, the intermolecular interactions between cholesterol and graphene will be directly measured via dual-trap optical tweezers at the single-molecule level. Moreover, ultrafast graphene field effect transistors will be utilized to explore the dynamics and distribution of cholesterol in cell membranes and then engineer cellular structure and function. These fundamental studies will not only provide new insights into mechanical coupling between biomolecules and nanomaterials, but also promote future interdisciplinary approaches for deciphering molecular and cellular mechanisms governing cell membranes. . In addition, this research will be integrated with an educational plan to promote science and engineering to students of all ages and backgrounds. The PI will coordinate with Vanderbilt?s Center for Science Outreach to extend research impact to K-12 students, foster interdisciplinary education and training to undergraduate and graduate students, and encourage women and underrepresented students in engineering and physics. 

Cholesterol is one of the most important lipid molecules involved in various interactions that shape the architecture and functionality of the cell membrane.   However, the understanding of the cell membrane and its cholesterol contents is far from complete. Recent studies have suggested that graphene can be utilized to directly and precisely manipulate the local cholesterol concentration in cell membranes and thus control specific transmembrane signaling pathways and associated cell behavior. This project will develop a graphene-based strategy to manipulate cellular structure and function with high spatiotemporal resolution. The approach is to use dual-trap optical tweezers to bring a single cholesterol molecule close to a suspended graphene transistor to directly measure the binding force between them. Based on the fundamental knowledge of molecular interface between cholesterol and graphene, ultrafast graphene field effect transistors will be used to manipulate local cholesterol concentration in the cell membrane in a controlled way. Simultaneously, the cellular structure will be monitored via fluorescence microscopy. These fundamental studies will not only provide an in-depth understanding of the bonding mechanisms between graphene and cholesterol, but also shed light on the knowledge of cholesterol dynamics and distribution in cell membranes, opening up entirely new avenues for future cellular engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project pursues fundamental understanding of the mechanical and electrical interactions between cells/biomolecules and two-dimensional (2D) materials, which play critical roles in the design and implementation of novel strategies to probe the physiological and pathological behaviors of cells and molecules. The outcomes of this project include (1) successful fabrication of various 2D materials-based microdevices and demonstration of their functionalities; (2) direct measurements of the binding force between two aromatic ring structures; (3)  observation of electrical interactions between cells and graphene membranes; (4) detection of electrophysiological activities of retina ganglion cells and axons in explanted mouse retina using graphene electrodes and transistors via electrical and optoelectronic recordings. Importantly, this project has partially supported the education of three Ph.D. students who were trained to conduct interdisciplinary research involving 2D materials synthesis, nanofabrication, and electronic/optoelectronic measurements. All three Ph.D. students have successfully completed their Ph.D. programs and joined the STEM work force.

First, under the support of this project, various 2D materials-based microdevices have been constructed, which include graphene nanoribbon/carbon nanotube transistors in microfluidic chambers, and graphene electrodes/transistors on flexible perforated polyimide substrate placed on top of microfluidic circuits. Importantly, great efforts have been made to ensure that the distance between the graphene electrodes/transistors and the bottom of the devices is short enough (< 250 micrometers) to allow for high-resolution optical microscopy examination of the biological samples, dual-trap optical tweezer manipulation of cells/biomolecules, and scanning photocurrent microscopy mapping of the optoelectronic response of the graphene transistors. More advanced versions of these platforms equipped with complex microfluidic circuits have the capabilities of controlling the microenvironments of the cells/molecules/tissues to enable local and global stimulation.

A key outcome obtained with these novel microfluidic platforms is the precise measurement of the interaction force between two aromatic rings, which are abundant in nature, and play critical roles in a wide variety of applications such as drug delivery. Previous efforts to determine this interaction force suffer from the large inertia force of the measurement probe, which renders significant larger values than the equilibrium force. Using dual-trap optical tweezers to pull a DNA from a carbon nanotube at an extremely slow loading rate, we were able to measure an interaction force of 1.2 ± 0.5 pN, which is due to the interaction between two aromatic rings with one on the single-walled carbon nanotube and one on the DNA. This value is significantly lower than previously reported value, but in good agreement with theoretical simulations.

In addition to the mechanical interactions, the graphene electrode/transistor-based microfluidic platforms allowed for measurements of electrical interactions between cells and graphene probes. In particular, these platforms were adopted to measure the electrical signals (action potentials) from retina ganglion cells (RGCs) and axons in explanted whole mouse retina. With the transparent graphene as the key sensing element, we were able to optically stimulate the neuronal processes directly on top of the graphene sensors. The integrated microfluidic circuit enabled precise control of the local chemical microenvironment. Taking advantage of these powerful device capabilities, we were able to record the electrical signals from the RGCs and axons in response to both optical and chemical stimulation. Importantly, the results show that the graphene electrode can lead to a higher sensitivity as compared to the more commonly used gold electrode. In addition, through modulating the local and global chemical microenvironments of the retina, we were able to show that the correlated response of multiple RGCs in neural networks in retina is due to signal transmission via gap junctions. Finally, we were able to correlate the electrical signals and the sources of these signals through high-magnification confocal imaging of the neuronal processes on top of the graphene probes.

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2024
Modified by: Sharon M Weiss
